Merinews reported that in September 2013, Al-Nusra damaged and plundered churches in Maaloula. This was a part of a campaign against the Christian region and a part of the attempt to convert the region to Islam.

The Irish Times reported that before November 27, 2013, rebel forces damaged the National Museum in Damascus. The firing of mortars only damaged the exterior of the building and not the museum's rich repository of Syria's historical treasures.
Xinhua News reported that on November 28, 2013, Assad forces damaged a church in Homs. In the shelling campaign, religious books were damaged in the destruction of the church.

The Associated Press reported that between November 14 and 29, 2013, rebel forces damaged the Great Umayyad mosque in Damascus. Mortar attacks on the mosque also damaged an internal mosaic and one of its entrances.

The BBC reported that on November 29, 2013, terrorists damaged the Great Umayyad Mosque in Damascus. The mosque is the earliest surviving stone mosque, built between 705 and 715 CE by the Umayyad Caliph al-Walīd.

The BBC reported that between November 1 and December 3, 2013, terrorists, using mortar attacks, destroyed the Great Umayyad Mosque in Damascus. This event resulted in the death of four citizens, including a child and a woman, and the injury of 26 others.

The BBC reported that betweeb November 1 and December 3, 2013, terrorists destroyed several religious shrines in Aleppo. The same terrorists were reponsible for the destruction of the Great Umayyad Mosque in Damascus.
Xinhua News Agency reported that between December 1 and 14, 2013, Assad forced damaged a graveyard when they shelled the Kadi Askar neighborhood of Aleppo.
The Wall Street Journal reported that between December 1 and 17, 2013, militants ransacked the main church in Deir Atiyah.

properties.sitename: Greek Catholic Church of Constantine and Elena
properties.description: The Kingston Whig Standard reported that in October 2013, government forces destroyed the Greek Catholic Church of Constantine and Helen in Yabroud. It was destroyed as a part of a shelling campaign by government forces, and it previously contained two explosives from previous warfare. The Church of Constantine and Helen in Yabroud was originally a pagan temple to the sun god Jupiter, and was converted to a church in about 300 AD by Emperor Constantine and Helena. It is one of the oldest churches in Syria.

Xinhua News Agency reported that on December 21, 2013, rebels damaged the Old Church in Daraa with mortars. The shells landed while Church volunteers were distributing charity aid to locals. The mortality of the event was 12 people with many others injured.

properties.sitename: statue of Abu Tammam Habib ibn Aws, Jasim
properties.description: The Independent reported that between January 1 and December 23, 2013, the Takfiri rebels blew up the statue of Abu Tammam Habib ibn Aws in Jasim. Abu Tammam Habib ibn Aws who was a Damascus native who produced an anthology of other poets in Armenia and Iran.

FARS News Network reported that on December 30, 2013, ISIS blasted the tomb of Setti Rahmah in Balshoun village in Jabal al-Zaviyah, Idlib countryside.The tomb was destroyed through the employment of Improvised Explosive Devices (IED).

The Middle East Journal reported that on July 28, 2014, the Khalid bin al-Walid Mosque in the Homs neighborhood of Khalidiyya sustained significant damaged caused by the struggle between Syrian armed forces and opposition groups. The current mosque was built on the ruins of those built in the 7th and 13th centuries to honor Khalid ibn al-Walid, an Arab military commander. The mosque is the site of an interior shrine that contains Khalid's tomb dates to the 11th century and is considered to be a significant pilgrimage center.
The Middle East Journal reported that on July 30, 2013, looters with bulldozer pillages sites in Apamea. Apamea is an ancient Greek and Roman city.
The Middle East Journal reported that on September 9, 2013, the Nusra Front and Qalamun Liberation Front burned a church in Maaloula. The church was burned before Syrian Armed Forces retook the city.
The Middle East Journal reported that on September 9, 2013, the Nusra Front and Qalamun Liberation Front robbed two churches in Maaloula.

The Middle East Journal reported that on October 13, 2013, ISIL destroyed the Shaykh 'Isa 'Abd al-Qadir al-Rifa'i shrine in Busayrah. The shrine was created in honor of Shaykh Abdul Qadir Isa, one of the revivers of the Sufi tradition in the Levant. He was thought to have reclaimed Islam’s spiritual riches and revived the spiritual path in an era of gross materialism.
BBC Monitoring Middle East reported that on January 1, 2014, Shayk Hilal Mosque was destroyed by ISIS. The mosque was known for being the site of Shakyh Hilal's grave.

Sputnik News Service reported that during the week of April 24, 2016, a mosque in Aleppo was destroyed. Heavy fire continued in the area during that week, and the U.S. Secretary of State condemned the Assad regime as it continued to “escalate the conflict by predominantly targeting innocent civilians and parties to the cessation of hostilities”.
The Nation reported that on April 27, 2016, rebel forces retaliated against government jets and hit a mosque in Aleppo with rockets.

Al Arabiya reported that between April 23 and May 2, 2016, the historic city of Aleppo was damaged in bombings, air strikes, and shelling.  The bombings left over 253 civilians dead, including 49 children.

Kazinform International News Agency reported that between April 2 and 21, 2016, Palmyra and ten other cultural heritage sites were cleared of mines and of explosive ordnance by Russian Armed Forces' International Mine Action Center. The Russian military next began demining Palmyra's residential area, where another 560 hectares of mines and ammunition need to be cleared.
NPR: Morning Edition reported before May 3, 2016, the Umayyad Mosque in Aleppo was damaged.

The New York Times reported that before May 3, 2016, the Old City of Aleppo, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, was sealed off by the Syrian military. The Old City was near the front lines, which divided the government-controlled Syria from rebel-held territory.

ANSAMED reported that on May 4, 2016, ISIS attacked government forces near Palmyra through suicide car bombs in order to secure control of a strategic natural gas field. The May 4 attack was a continuation of a 3-day period in which ISIS attempted to take back the gas field from the Syrian government forces and its allies. Palmyra is a UNESCO World Heritage site, and Syrian government forces and ISIS have been battling over control of the area.

DPA reported that sometime between April 22 and May 4, 2016, shelling and fire from government forces toppled the minaret of the central Umayyad Mosque in Aleppo. Aleppo was reported to be the last major urban center in rebel hands, and the Aleppo province is one of the most critical battlegrounds in the war.

FARS News Agency reported that in May 2016, heavy fire and bombardments by the Syrian regime caused the al-Nusra Front, Nouriddeen al-Zinki movement, and Jeish al-Muhajireen Wal Ansar to withdraw forces from the Great Prophet Mosque in Aleppo. The terrorists also withdrew forces from the Al-Zahra Association Quarter, the Air Force Intelligence (AFI) building, and al-Zahra-Lairamoun axis. The terrorists’ aim was to attack the Syrian government forces' strongholds across Aleppo's Northern and Northwestern districts, but at least 70 members of the terrorist groups were killed during the groups’ failed attacks.

Handelsblatt Global Edition reported that between December 1, 2012, and July 31, 2013, the Syrian regime targeted the Abed Elkader- Al Husaini Mosque and Al Faluja school in Yarmouk with airstrikes. Yarmouk became a prime city for refugees fleeing rebel cities that were under attack from Assad’s regime, but the government turned its focus to the city after opposition fighters of the Free Syria Army. The mosque and the school were refugee centers, and many were forced to leave the city of Yarmouk. In July 2013, a partial blockade orchestrated by the regime trapped around 20,000 civilians in the city.

The Peninsula reported that between April 21 and May 4, 2016, a mosque in al-Sokkari was targeted by a regime warplane. The Assad regime, assisted by Russian air support, repeatedly bombarded opposition-held regions of Aleppo.

Xinhua News Agency reported that during the week of May 15, 2016, the Islamic State (IS) launched attacks on Palmyra to recapture the city after losing it to the Syrian government. Palmyra is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and IS militants have been using it as a strategic location for war efforts.

Macau Daily Times reported that on May 10, 2016, the dome of a mosque in Binnish, a town of the province Idlib, was knocked out by airstrikes. Sources are not in agreement on whether the warplanes were Syrian or Russian. A commander of a militia of the Jaish al-Fatah coalition, which is made up of Syrian branches of Al-Qaida, was killed during the raids, and Binnish is known for being a Jaish al-Fatah stronghold.

Asharq Al-Awsat reported that on May 11 or 12, 2016, a mosque in Aleppo was leveled as a result of Iranian – Russian hostilities. A first Iranian-Russian attack took place in February but was unsuccessful and left dozens of troops dead.  The article argues for a cessation for hostilities in the area.

DESMENA reported that before May 12, 2016, the Church of St. Mary of the Holy Belt in the city of Homs was badly damaged. Homs is known as the “capital of the revolution”, as it led an uprising against President Assad’s regime, and the city was victim to mortars, rockets, and barrel bombs.

Agence French Press reported that during January 2016, the Takfiris and jihadists attacked the Sayeda Zeinab mausoleum through a triple explosion. 70 people were killed, and the mausoleum was involved in numerous attacks during 2016.

Reuters News reported that between February 1 and May 13, 2016, indiscriminate armed attacks damaged mosques in the Sheikh Maqsoud district of Aleppo. The attacks were part of fighting between the Kurdish YPG militia and rebel groups, but in the process, mosques, civilians, streets, and markets were struck. Over 83 civilians, including 30 children were killed during the fighting.

PARALL and FARS News Agency reported that before May 13, 2016, armed groups surrounding the predominantly Kurdish Sheikh Maqsoud district of Aleppo have carried out attacks on mosques. Increasing evidence indicates chemical weapons were used, and weapons used by armed groups were reported to be typically home-made and cannot be “accurately aimed at specific targets”. No specific mosque was named.

RIA Novosti reported that between February 1 and May 13, 2016, the Ahrar al-Sham terrorist group was using chemical warfare to attack mosques in Aleppo. Missiles are specifically being reported that ejected white or yellow phosphorus munitions, home-made “Hamim” rockets, projectiles fitted with gas canisters known as “hell cannons”.

The French News Agency reported that on May 13, 2016, explosions from Takfiri artillery bombardments rocked the Damascus airport near the Sayyida Zeinab shrine. The attack killed the top Hezbolla military commander, Mustafa Badreddine. Hezbolla has a has wide presence and several military positions around the Sayyida Zeinab shrine.
Scroll.in reported that before May 15, 2016, a mosque in Aleppo was destroyed.
TASS World Service reported that between January 1, 2012, and May 16, 2016, people looted Syrian archaeological treasures from the ancient city of Palmyra.

The Canadian Press and the Guardian reported that  before May 17, 2016, the Russian military was constructing a base after the Palmyra UNESCO World Heritage Site was controlled by ISIS militants. Construction of the base, including barracks, offices, and clinics, began on the northern edge of the site that was previously damaged by ISIS, and was done so without permission.
Sputnik News Service reported that on May 17, 2016, the Syrian army captured Daesh jihadist group commander Ahmad Mursid al-Iraqi during a raid in Palmyra. Palmyra is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

36th Parallel reported that between May 12 and May 16, 2016 ,an airstrike hit the St. Simeon monestary, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, in the Ancient Villages of Northern Syria. The Church of Saint Simeon suffered severe damage, specifically to the pillars where it is said Saint Simeon spent forty years as a hermit, the facade, which was holed, and the nave, where the missile struck.

The BBC reported that on between March 1 and May 18, 2016, Russian airstrikes, Syrian soldiers, tanks, missile systems, mortars, cannons firing, and missiles damaged the ancient city of Palmyra. The city is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and was used as a strategic location by ISIS. Efforts to remove mines and to restore destroyed buildings were being administered at the time of the report.

The Guardian reported that on May 22, 2016, ISIS claimed several bombings near the Sayyida Zaynab Mosque in Damascus. The first blast was caused by a car bomb, and the next two were caused by suicide bombers. Over fifty people were killed and 120 were injured. The Sayyida Zaynab Mosque is a known pilgrimage site for Shia Muslims living in nearby countries of Iran, Lebanon, and others. The attacks were conducted in response to UN peace talks where Syrian government and opposition officials participated.

The Guardian reported that on October 1, 2015, Russian defense military forces bombed the Omar Bin Al Khattab Mosque in Jisr al-Shughour, Idlib, destroying minarets and killing at least two. On October 30, the Russians denied having hit the mosque, and instead argued that they hit the Al Farooq mosque, but aerial footage shown by the Atlantic Council showed otherwise. Russians also denied targeting other cities, civilians, and mosques, but the Atlantic Council’s aerial photographs showed Russian targets have been outside of ISIS controlled territory.

The Guardian reported that from July 2015 to May 2016, Russian airstrikes, ISIS land mines and booby traps, and Syrian military forces have been targeting Palmyra. Palmyra is a UNESCO World Heritage site and was Syria’s most popular tourist attraction. ISIS destroyed 3 temples, including the Temple of Bel, Temple of Baalshamin, the Arch of Triumph, lower tombs, and a lion statue at Palmyra's entrance soon after seizing the ancient city in 2011 and used an ancient Roman amphitheater as a location for executions. Syrian forces, backed by the Russian military, gained back the city in 2015, which served as a military success symbol for them. ISIS is planting mines and booby traps in attempts to regain it as it is used as a channel for personnel and equipment.

The Guardian reported that before May 27, 2016, the Great Mosque of Aleppo was nearly destroyed due to shelling, barrel bombs, and artillery fire.  Aleppo has a strategic location close to Turkey, where supply lines and refugees can pass through.

The Saudi Gazette reported that for three months in 2014, the Crac des Chevaliers castle was occupied by rebels and damaged by mortar fires. The castle is a 900-year-old UNESCO World Heritage site, and French archaeologists are attempting to repair the damage done to the site, caused by shrapnel and bomb damage. Additional ancient cities of Homs and Aleppo are reported to be in ruins.

FARS News Agency reported that on May 28 or 29, 2016, a bomb-laden car exploded near the Shuaib Mosque in the al-Dhabit district of Idlib. Over 30 were killed in the blast, including field commanders and guards of the al-Qaeda affiliated al-Nursa Front and some civilians. No party has claimed responsibility for the attack, but ISIL is known for carrying out bombings in the area. Idlib was reported to be a strategic location to dispatch terrorists and military equipment from Idlib to Aleppo.
BBC Monitoring Middle East reported that on May 29, 2016, Mohammad Davud Khademi was killed while defending holy shrine of Zaynab, the granddaughter of Prophet Muhammad.

Indo-Asian News Service reported that between May 26 and 30, 2016, the Syrian army uncovered a new mass burial site in the ancient ruins of Palmyra, Syria. IS militants seized the “significantly important location” in 2015 and are known to kill civilians and dump bodies there. Workers trying to repair the ruins find other graves almost every 10-15 days.

The Daily Herald and The Times of Israel reported that on May 31, 2016, Russian military forces conducted around 10 airstrikes on targeted mosques, two hospitals, a public garden, and local neighborhoods in Idlib, Syria, killing at least 60 and wounding 200. Idlib is controlled by Al-Qaeda affiliate group Nusra Front and was targeted by Russia to back up the capital city Damascus to force other rebel groups to withdraw from Nusra Front. All sites mentioned were seriously damaged.
Al Jazeera reported that on June 2, 2016, a suicide bomb attack occurred at Khulafa Rashideen Mosque in Latakia, killing two people.

BBC reported that on June 5, 2016, an Farah Church, an Armenian Catholic church, was struck with a missile in Al-Midan, a neighborhood in northern Aleppo. Large material damage was reported at the location.

CNN reported that on June 27, 2016, airstrikes from either the Russian or Syrian military hit a mosque in the eastern part of Deir Ezzor, killing 82 civilians, including 25 children. While it is unclear whether it was the Syrian or Russian airforce, sources say that the airstrikes are similar to airstrikes that have been undertaken by both militaries.

BBC Monitoring reported that on July 3, 2016, a suicide bomber entered into a mosque in Jasem and detonated. The suicide bomber was a member of the Liwaa Shuhada al-Yarmouk army which is a part of the Khalid Bin l-Waleed Army which is linked to the Islamic State.
Independent online reported that before July 4, 2016, that the Umayyad Mosque oin Aleppo was destroyed.
The Statesman reported that on July 8, 2016, videos were released showing Islamic State militants destroying statues and running over mummies with a lorry in Palmyra.
The Canadian Press reported that on July 14, 2016, Syrian military airstrikes on rebel-held areas of Aleppo hit a mosque in the Tariq al-Bab neighborhood.

Sputnik News Service reported that on July 11, 2016, the Aleppo National Museum was hit by heavy shelling which damaged the building's structure and roof. This shelling was a result of continuing conflict in Aleppo and many exhibitions that content extensive examples of Syrian archeology were placed at risk.
AKEIN reported that on November 11, 2013, the Church of the Cross was attacked in Damascus. The attack killed two individuals and damaged part of the church.

Itar-TASS World Service reported that before November 18, 2013, the FSA destroyed the Great Umayyad Mosque in Aleppo. Built in the 8th century, the mosque is home to the remains of Zechariah, the father of John the Baptist, both of whom are revered in Islam and Christianity. The Great Umayyad Mosque in Aleppo is a UNESCO World Heritage site and the home to a museum containing a number of ancient manuscript, a variety of valuable items like a box containing a strand of Prophet Muhammad's hair, multiple shrines and tombs, a haram, and traditional Islamic architecture.

NSONL reported that between November 17 and 23, 2013, the Syrian army occupied the Cherubim Monastery in Damascus and turned it into a military base. It is said that government troops deployed heavy weapons inside the historic Orthodox monastery located at an altitude of 2000 metres on the highest peak of Mount Qalamoun. The monastery is dedicated to the cherubim and seraphim, the highest ranks of angels, who occupy the summit of the celestial hierarchy.
Agence France Presse reported that on August 29, 2012, the Al-Nasar Mosque in Aleppo was shelled by government forces.

The Washington Post reported that before February 13, 2013, Bronze Age vessels were looted from Tell Shihab. Tell Shihab is believed to be the site of the ancient city of Yeno’am and is the home to many artifacts from the 1300s BCE.

The Washington Post reported that between January 1 and March 13, 2013, Bronze Age vessels were looted from Tell Shihab. Tell Shihab is believed to be the site of the ancient city of Yeno’am and is the home to many artifacts from the 1300s BCE.
FARS News Agency reported that on January 1, 2014, ISIS detonated weapons on the Shrine of Prophet Ayoub's wife in Idlib.
Reuters reported that on January 8, 2014, forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad damaged a mosque in an airstike in Arbin.

The Statesman reported that between January 9, 2013, and January 9, 2014, millitants descrated and burned parts of the Holy Shrine of Lady Sakinah in Damascus. The namesake of the shrine, Sakinah, was the daughter of Hussein Ibn Ali, an important figure in Shi'a Islam.

Kashmir Monitor reported that on January 1, 2014, Al-Qaeda linked militants vandalized, burned and robbed a church in Maaloula. Maaloula has a large Christian population and is one of three remaining villages where Western Neo-Aramaic is spoken.
Al Akhbar reported that befor January 21, 2014, radical militants attacked with explosives an Evangelical Church in Aleppo.
Al Akhbar reported that before January 21, 2014, radical militants attacked with explosives several churches and monasteries in Aleppo.
The Independent Online reported that beween March 1, 2013, and January 26, 2014, unspecified actors badly damaged a mosque in Barzeh.
The Guardian reported that before January 27, 2014, air force jets bombed the Souq al-Madina in Aleppo. The Souq al-Madina is one of the oldest covered marketplaces in the world.

The Guardian reported that before January 27, 2014, air forces jets bombed the Citadel in Aleppo. The Aleppo Citadel is part of the UNESCO World Heritage Site of Ancient City of Aleppo and one of the oldest castles in the world.
The Guardian reported that before January 27, 2014, jets and artillery shelled Crac de Chevaliers castle in Homs. The Crac de Chevaliers castle is a Medieval castle and UNESCO World Heritage Site.
The New York Post reported in April 2013, Syrian President Assad's forces shelled the Omari Mosque in Daraa. The mosque is more than 13 centuries old.
Naples Daily News reported that on February 4, 2014, Syrian forces bombed on the Uthman Bin Affan Mosque in Aleppo.

The Philippines News Agency reported on February 5, 2014, extremist terrorists launched a missile attack on the Shrine of Lady Sakinah in Damascus. The namesake of the shrine, Sakinah, was the daughter of Hussein Ibn Ali, an important figure in Shi'a Islam.

Trend News Agency reported ithat betwwen June 1, 2012, and August 31, 2012, the Syrian army destroyed the Khalid Ibn Walid Mosque in Homs. The Khalid Ibn Walid Mosque is named for a famous Muslim military commander from the 7th Century.
The Independent Online reported between January 10 and 20, ISIS blew up and destroyed Byzantine mosaics in Al Raqqa.
The Independent Online reported that before February 13, 2014, Islamic fundamentalists destroyed reliefs at the Shash Hamdan cemetery in Dżudajdat Mustaha.
The Independent Online reported that before February 13, 2014, Islamic fundamentalists destroyed statues in the al-Qatora valley.
The Independent Online reported that before February 13, 2014, looters looted a cave in Ebla. Ebla is an ancient city and important archaeological site.
The Hamilton Spectator reported that on February 15, 2014, a car bomb damaged a mosque in Yadudah.
The Philippines News Agency reported that before February 15, 2014, al-Nusra Front fighters looted archaeological objects from the city of Maaloula. Maaloula is a predominately Christian city.
The Philippines News Agency reported that before February 15, 2014, thieves illegally exacatvated and placed explosives in Tell al-Achari in Daraa.
Global Data Point reported on February 27, 2014, ISIL blew up the Shrine of Mashuq Khaznawi in Tell Marouf.
FARS News Agency reported that on March 5, 2014, ISIL detonated the Suleyman Shah Tomb in Manbij.
Associated Press Newswires reported in October 2013, ISIL damaged the Church of Saidat al-Bishara in Raqqa.

The International New York Times reported that before December 31, 2012, looters illegaly execavated and damaged the Apamea archaeological site in Qalaat al-Madiq. Apamea is an ancient city founded in 301 BC.

The International New York Times reported that nefore March 8, 2014, thieves looted the archaelogical site of Dura Europos. Dura Europos is an ancient Syrian city and an important archaeological site.

The International New York Times reported that before March 8, 2014, rebels and the Syrian Army damaged the Crac des Chevaliers castle in Homs. The Crac des Chevaliers castle is a Medieval castle and UNESCO World Heritage Site.
Reuters Pictures reported that on March 7, 2014, unspecificed actors damaged a mosque in Deir Ezzor.
Voice of America reported that before March 12, 2014, unspecified actors damaged the ancient city of Palmyra. Palmyra is an ancient city and UNESCO World Heritage Site.

Voice of America reported that before March 12, 2014, unspecified actors damaged the Cathedral of St. Siemon Stylite. The ancient church is a part of the "Ancient Villages of Northern Syria" UNESCO World Heritage Site.

Xinhua News Agency reported that on March 20, 2014, unspecificed actors damaged the Crac des Chevaliers castle in Homs. The Crac des Chevaliers Castle is a Medieval castle and UNESCO World Heritage Site.

M2 Presswire reported that before March 12, 2014, unspecified actors damaged the Aleppo Citadel. The Aleppo Citadel is part of the UNESCO World Heritage Site of Ancient City of Aleppo and one of the oldest castles in the world.

M2 Presswire reported that during before March 12, 2014, unspecified actors damaged the Crac des Chevaliers castle in Homs. The Crac des Chevaliers castle is a medival castle and UNESCO World Heritage Site.
M2 Presswire reported that before March 12, 2014, unspecified actors damaged the Apamea archaeological site in Qalaat al-Madiq. Apamea was an ancient city founded in 301 BC.
M2 Presswire reported that before March 12, 2014, unspecified actors damaged Palmyra. Palmyra is an ancient city and UNESCO World Heritage Site.

M2 Presswire reported that before March 12, 2014, unspecified actors damaged Salah al-Din's Castle, also known as Qal'at Salah El-Din in Al-Haffah. Qal'at Salah El-Din is a Medieval castle and UNESCO World Heritage Site.
Tempo reported that during the Syrian conflict, gunmen looted archaeological warehouses in Al Raqqa.

The Daily Telegraph reported that before March 14, 2014, the Syrian regime destroyed the Great Umayyad Mosque in Aleppo. The Great Umayyad Mosque is one of the oldest mosques in Syria and located in the Ancient City of Aleppo World Heritage Sites.
The Times Literary Supplement reported that before March 14, 2014, terrorists held looted archaeologial funerary objects from Palmyra. Palmyra is an ancient city and UNESCO World Heritage Site.

properties.sitename: Greek Catholic Church of Our Lady
properties.description: The Independent Online reported that between March 4 and 17, 2014, Jabhat al-Nusra and the Islamic Front vandalized the Greak Catholic Church of Our Lady in Yabroud.
FARS News Agency reported that between April 1, 2013 and March 27, 2014, ISIS targeted churches in Maaloula.
FARS News Agency reported that betweem April 1, 2013, and March 27, 2014, ISIS targeted Sayyida Zeynab Mosque in Babbila.
The Irish Times reported that on May 7th, 2014, a Syrian commander torched the churches in Homs. Among the churches burned was the Umm Al-Zennar Syriac Orthodox cathedral.

The BBC Monitoring Middle East reported that on June 7, 2014, the Syrian army bombed multiple neighborhoods and sites in Aleppo. The Haroun Dadeh Mosque was among the sites destroyed by the helicopter bombings
The BBC Monitoring Middle East reported that on June 7, 2014, the Syrian army bombed multiple neighborhoods and sites in Aleppo, including the Bader Mosque.
The ARMENPRESS News Wire reported that on March 23, 2014, extremist groups took over Kessa. The extremist group pillaged Armenian houses, destroyed churches, and took Armenian families hostage.
The Irish Times reported that between March 1 and 31, 2013, jihadist groups terrorized Christians around eastern Syria. In Al Raqqa, the jihadists destroyed churches and other Christian sites.

properties.sitename: Saint Mary Church of the Holy belt
properties.description: Al Arabiya reported that between March 15, 2011 and June 20, 2014, workers repairing the damaged Saint Mary Church in Homs, whose foundation dates from the A.D. 50, had found evidence that someone tried to dig up the church's Holy Girdle of Mary relic.
Al Arabiya reported that between March 15, 2011 and June 20, 2014, workers repairing the home of a Christian citizen found a statue of the Virgin Mary smashed.
Inter Press Service reported that between April 9, 2014, and May 9, 2014, insurgents heavily damaged the St. George Church in the Old City of Homs.
The New York Times reported that between April 1, 2013 and July 24, 2014, the Islamic State destroyed statues and sites they considered blasphemus in Al Raqqa.
The Spiegel Online International reported that, between January 1, 2012, and December 31, 2012, the Aleppo's ancient city, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, sufferd extensive damage from the war.

The Spiegel Online International reported that, between March 15, 2011 and August 8, 2014, the excavation site of the ancient city, Tell Brak,  was looted of tools and ceramics that had been left. Tell Brak is an ancient Mesopotamian city dating back 6,000 years and is considered on of the world's first cities.

Agence France-Presse reported on September 2, 2014, rebel fighters blew up colonial-era and other historic buildings in Aleppo. The historic buildings dated back to 1930, and were previously used by Aleppo's police leadership.

ARM Info News reported that on September 21, 2014, the Islamic State targeted and exploded the Armenian St. Nahatakats Martyrs Church in Deir Ezzor. The church was attacked on the Armenian Independence day.
The BBC Monitoring Middle East reported that on October 14, 2014, terrrorists shot the Abd-al-Rahman al-Siddik Mosque in Damascus.

The Asian News International reported that on November 25, 2014, the Syrian forces conducted airstrikes around Al Raqqa, hitting the city's historic souq. Raqqa was targeted because it is considered to be the Islamis State's capitol city.

The Asian News International reported that on November 25, 2014, the Syrian forces conducted airstrikes around Al Raqqa, hitting the al-Hani Mosque. Al Raqqa was targeted because it is considered to be the Islamis State's capitol city.

Sputnik News Service reported that on January 1, 2015, mortar rounds fired by Islamic State extremists exploded near the al-Zahra mosque in Aleppo. Government forces had recently regained control of that part of the city.
Reuters reported that on January 1, 2015, Syrian forces fired a missile at the al-Bayyada mosque in Aleppo. The mosque was seriously damaged.
The Telegraph reported that between March 21, 2014, and January 3, 2015, rebels destroyed graves in Kessab. According to residents, they smashed gravestones and drew graffiti.
BBC reported that on January 2, 2015, armed terrorist organizations fired mortar shells at the University of Damascus' Faculty of Law Garden. The attack caused material damage to the site.

The Telegraph reported that between March 21, and January 3, 2011, rebels burned down churches in Kessab. The churches targeted include the Holy Trinity Armenian Evangelical church and the Armenian Apostolic church.
The Daily Star reported that between March 15, 2011 and January 6, 2015, the ancient city of Aleppo was badly damaged. The ancient city of Aleppo is one of Syria's six UNESCO World Heritage sites.

Indo-Asian News Service reported that between September 1, 2012, and September 30, 2012, the Islamic State destroyed churches in Deir Ezzor province. One of the churches targeted was the Al-Bukamal church.
BBC reported that on January 7, 2015, members of Jabhat al-Nusrah demolished the Al-Imam al-Nawawi shrine in Nawa. Al-Nawawi was a 13th-century Sunni jurist and hadith scholar.

The Associated Press reported that on January 8, 2015, the Nusra Front shelled and destroyed Shiite mosques in northern Syria. The predominantly Sunni Nusra Front views minority Shiites as apostates who are worthy of death.

The Associated Press reported that on January 8, 2015, the Nusra Front shelled and destroyed Shiite mosques in northern Syria. The predominantly Sunni Nusra Front views minority Shiites as apostates who are worthy of death.
Reuters reported that between March 15, 2011, and January 9, 2015, forces loyal to Assad dropped barrel bombs on graves in Aleppo. The graves were badly damaged in the attack.
ARKA News and BBC reported that on January 9, 2015, terrorists attacked St. Rita Armenian Catholic Church in Aleppo. About 60,000 Armenians live in Aleppo.

Channel NewsAsia reported that between March 15, 2011, and January 22, 2015, Islamic State fighters destroyed a 400-year-old Sufi mosque in Kawkab. The Islamic State has targeted Sufi mosques and shrines throughout the conflict.
The Associated Press reported that on January 23, 2015, a government airstrike hit a mosque in Damascus. At least thirty-five people were killed.

Al Arabiya reported that between March 15, 2011 an January 26, 2015, Syrian opposition forces destroyed a bust of Hafez al-Assad in Daraa. Hafez al-Assad was the president of Syria from 1971 to 2000, and is the father of Bashar al-Assad.
BBC reported that on January 28, 2015, jihadists blew up part of the wall of the Umayyad mosque in Aleppo. The city of Aleppo was registered as a UNESCO World Heritage site in 1986.

Dow Jones Institutional News reported that on February 1, 2015, a bomb attack hit a bus carrying Shiite pilgrims near the historic Souq al-Hamidiyah marketplace in Damascus. At least six people were killed.
BBC reported that on February 2, 2015, the Syrian army fired at Islamic State vehicles occupying Al Bara archaeological site. The extent of damage to the site is unclear.
Indo-Asian News Service reported that on February 5, 2015, rocket attacks fired by rebels hit the Zeitoun Church in Damascus. Forty-two people were killed in the attacks.
Indo-Asian News Service  and Thai News Service reported that on February 5, 2015, rocket attacks fired by rebels hit the Umayyad mosque in Damascus. Multiple people were killed in the attacks.

ForeignAffairs reported that on February 5, 2015, rocket fire and mortar shells hit St. Paul's Franciscan Monastery in Damascus. The Conversion of St. Paul church attached to the monastery was not affected.

Foreign Affairs reported that between January 1 and January 31, 2015, Islamic State fighters ransacked the local church in the village of Tell Hamees. ISIS also forced villagers to remove the cross from the church's dome.

The Wall Street Journal reported that between June 1, 2014, and February 11, 2015, the Islamic State looted the Mesopotamian city of Mari. Archaeologists counted more than 1,300 illegal excavation pits using satellite imagery.
The Wall Street Journal reported that between January 1, and December 31, 2014, the Islamic State looted al-Nabek. The city is known for its early Christian icons and mosaics.

The Wall Street Journal reported that between June 1, 2014, and February 11, 2015, the Islamic State looted and destroyed historic buildings in Al Raqqa. Al Raqqa ia home to many ancient shrines which ISIS regards as sacrilegious.

The Wall Street Journal reported that between March 15, 2011, and February 11, 2015, forces loyal to Assad looted the site of Palmyra. A video posted to YouTube shows soldiers loading Palmyrene grave reliefs onto a truck.
Kuwait News Agency and BBC reported that on February 13, 2015, a car exploded near the al-Zahraa mosque in Damascus. At least ten people were killed.

DPA International Service and other news outlets reported that on February 23, 2015, ISIS burned down churches in Tell Hermez, including one of the most ancient churches in Syria. Christians in the town were also abducted by the group.
DPA International Service and other news outlets reported that on February 23, 2015, ISIS burned down churches in Tell Shamiran. Christians in the village were also abducted by the group.

The Daily Star and other news outlets  reported that between February 23 and February 24, 2015, ISIS set fire to as many as two churches in Tell Tamr. The attack came after the burning of churches in two neighboring villages, Tell Hermez and Tell Shamiram.
BBC reported that on February 27, 2015, a car bomb exploded near the al-Salam Mosque in al-Naseriyya. A number of civilians were wounded in the attack.
The Daily Star reported that on February 27, 2015, a car bomb detonated outside the Bilal Mosque in Dumair. Eight people were reportedly killed.

ARMENPRESS reported that in September 2014, Islamic State militants bombed the Armenian Genocide Martyrs' Memorial Church, an Armenian Church and Museum in Deir Ezzor. The museum was dedicated to the victims of the Armenian genocide.
Reuters reported that on March 3, 2015, a mosque in Bashkoy was badly damaged during fighting between forces loyal to Assad and rebels. It is unknown which group caused the damage.

The Associated Press reported that between June 1, 2014, and March 6, 2015, the Islamic State looted the site of Dura Europos. Satellite imagery showed the site pockmarked with looter's pits. Dura Europos was founded 2,300 years ago and is home to pagan temples, churches, and one of the earliest known synagogues.

The Associated Press reported that between June 1, 2014, and March 6, 2015, the Islamic State looted the site of Tell Ajaja in Hassakeh province. Tell Ajaja is known for its prehistoric settlement mounds.

The Associated Press reported that between June 1, 2014, and March 6, 2015, the Islamic State looted the site of Tell Brak in Hassakeh province. Tell Brak is known for its prehistoric settlement mounds.
Kuwait News Agency reported that on March 13, 2015, a missile fired by the Syrian government hit a mosque in Douma. Four civilians were killed in the attack.
BBC reported that on March 13, 2015, terrorists fired a mortar shell at the dome of the Sinan Agha Mosque in Damascus. The mosque was badly damaged.

Agence French Press reported that between November 11 and 29, 2014, the Syrian government bombed a mosque. Amnesty International accused the regime of intentionally targeting the mosque and civilians.
The Irish Times reported that between March 15, 2011, and March 20, 2015, looters pillaged the ancient Assyrian site of Dur-Katlimmu in Al-Hasakah province.
Financial Times reported that on March 28, 2015, Al-Nusra destroyed a statue of Hafez al-Assad in Idlib. Assad was the president of Syria from 1971 to 2000, and is the father of Bashar al-Assad.

The Art Media Agency reported that on April 1, 2015, the Archaelogical Museum in Idlib was damaged in a series of aerial strikes around the city. The wall of the museum was damaged, leaving the museum vulnerable to looting.
Reuters Photos photographed local Syrian residents inspecting the damage to a mosque after it had been set on fire.
Reuters reported that between June 1, 2014 and April 3, 2015, looters pillaged museums in Al Raqqa. The Syrian government estimates that more than 1,500 artifacts have been stolen.
Reuters reported that between March 25 and April 3, 2015, forces loyal to Assad shelled a mosque in Idlib. The mosque was badly damaged.

Agence France Presse reported on April 5, 2015, Easter Sunday, that the Islamic State had booby-trapped and bombed the Virgin Mary Church in Tell Nasra, Syria. At 80 years old, the Virgin Mary Church was one of three Christian churches in the town.
Reuters reported that in April 2014, a mosque in Al Sakhour was damaged by a series of barrel bomb attacks.

Reuters reported that between March 15, 2011, and May 31, 2015, a mosque in Aleppo was damaged by a series of barrel bombs by the Syrian government.The mosque was located in the old city of Aleppo, which dates back to the 12th century. 23 mosques were bombed in this set of barrel bombs.
The Herald reported that in June 2015, the al-Nusra Front had recently destroyed shrines and dug up graves in a Druze village.

The Daily Telegraph reported that on June 13, 2015, the wall next to the Bel-Shamin Temple in Palmyra suffered damages after an ISIL initiated airstrike. The Temple of Bel-Shamin dates back to the 2nd century B.C.

Agence French Press reported that on June 16, 2015, mosaics and the library at the Ma'arrat Al-Nu'man Mosaic Museum were damaged by barrel bombs. Portions of the museum had been sandbagged, protecting certain mosaics. The artifacts and mosaics date back to the late Roman Empire and the Byzantine Empire.

Agence French Press reported that on June 23, 2015, ISIS blew up the Mohammed bin Ali Shrine. The tombs damaged in the attack held a descendent of the Prophet Mohammed's cousin and a prominent religious figure from Palmyra.

Agence French Press reported that on June 23, 2015, ISIS blew up the Nizar Abu Bahaaeddine Shrine. The tombs damaged in the attach held a descendent of the Prophet Mohammed's cousin and a prominent religious figure from Palmyra.
Agence French Press reported that on June 27, 2015, the Allat Lion statue outside the Palmyra Museum was destroyed by ISIS. The statue dated back to the 1st Century BCE.

Reuters reported that on July 3, 2015, a suicide bomber set off an explosion in the Salem Mosque in Ariha, Syria, also known as Jerichol. This is considered to be one of the oldest, if not the oldest, mosques in Jericho. The attack was intended to kill the Nusra Front members who were meeting in the mosque; between 25 and 31 people died.

Agence French Press reported on September 21, 2015 that approximately 25 percent of the castle walls in the ancient city of Palmyra, Syria were destroyed in a heavy bombardment by the Syrian regime. Multiple other ancient monuments within the site have been damaged earlier in the conflict, including the Temple of Bel.

ANSAMED reported that on October 25, 2019, the Latin Church of Aleppo was targeted by a mortar shell, fired by anti-Assad rebels, while mass was underway. The shell exploded outside the church, damaging the building, but did not injure the 400 worshippers inside.

Agence French Press reported that on February 21, 2016, ISIS conducted 4 blasts, including car bombs, a propane gas canister, and at least 2 suicide bombers, near the most important holy Shiite shrine, Sayyida Zeynab, in Damascus. The mosque contains the tomb of the Prophet Mohammad’s granddaughter, Zaynab, which also serves as a center for religious studies for the Shiite sect of Islam and as a destination for mass pilgrimage.

CNN: Early Start and Pakistan Today reported that an Aleppo mosque and a clinic were targeted by jet missiles. The attack on the MSF-assisted pediatric hospital killed over 50, including one of the last pediatricians in the city, and the attack on the mosque left at least two dead as worshippers were leaving the mosque after the weekly prayers.
Agence French Press reported that in April 2013, the minaret of Aleppo’s Ummayad Mosque collapsed during fierce fighting.

Al Jazeera reported that during the week of April 29, 2016, three mosques in Bustan Qaser and al-Qoba were destroyed. Al Jazeera attributed the attacks to the Syrian government, but the military denied these claims. The strikes also hit 3 clinics in the rebel held districts of the city.
Associated Press Newswires reported that during 2012, a minaret of an Umayyad Mosque in Aleppo collapsed due to fighting.

CBS News: Evening News reported that on April 29,2016, a Muslim holy day, many attacks in Aleppo occurred around mosques. The Syrian regime, assisted by Russia and Iran, had been attempting to recapture all of Aleppo, where many rebels fight against the government forces.
DPA International Service reported that on April 29, 2016, regime warplanes struck an Aleppo Mosque. The airstrikes targeted rebel-held areas in Aleppo and killed 11 civilians.
Sputnik News Service reported that on April 29, 2016, a mosque was shelled by militants. At least 25 people were killed and 40 were injured.

Interfax: Russia & CIS General Newswire reported that on April 30, 2016, mortar shelling by Liwa Fursan al-Haq killed 15 and injured over 50 near the Malahoni Mosque in the Bab al-Faraj neighborhood in Aleppo.

The New York Times reported that on April 29, 2016, rocket barrages from rebels, possibly al-Qaeda affiliate Jabhat al-Nusra, damaged the Malla Khan mosque in Aleppo. Shelling and strikes were fired into the government-held Bab al-Faraj after Friday prayers and killed 15 worshippers and wounded 30 others.

Saudi Press Agency reported that between March 15, 2011, and April 30, 2016, Syrian regime airstrikes have targeted mosques, residential areas, and health facilities in Aleppo, resulting in over 200 civilians’ deaths, including children.

The Irish Mirror reported that on November 15, 2015, airstrikes carried out by the French army hit a museum in Raqqa, Syria. It is reported the museum was being used as a jail by ISIS at the time of the strikes.

FARS News Agency reported that between November 8 and 10, 2015, the Syrian Army destroyed the western portion of the al-Ansar Mosque in Douma, Syria. The al-Ansar Mosque had been previously struck by shelling.

Phillipines News Agency reported that before November 7, 2015, militants blew up the western entrance to the Aleppo Citadel in Aleppo, Syria. The Citadel is a fortified medival palace that is part of the Ancient City of Aleppo UNESCO World Heritage Site.

DPA International Service in English reported that between March 15, 2011, and November 4, 2015, Russian and Syrian airstrikes as well as looters had damaged the village of al-Bara in Jabal al-Zawiyeh, Syria. Al-Bara is an abandoned Byzantine village part of the Ancient Villages of Northern Syria on the UNESCO World Heritage List.

ARMENPRESS News Wire reported that between March 15, 2011, and November 4, 2015, ISIS burned an Armenian Orthodox Church in Tell Abyad, Syria. Before the church was burned it was defaced and used as a prison by ISIS.
Unian reported that on November 2, 2015, Russian airstrikes hit the historic castle in Palmyra, Syria. The castle is part of the Palmyra UNESCO World Heritage site and was under ISIS control.

Phillipines News Agency reported that between March 15, 2015, and November 25, 2015, armed militants looted and destroyed parts of the ancient city of Palmyra. Palmyra is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

Sputnik News Service reported that between March 15, 2011, and December 15, 2015, Daesh razed a large Christian cathedral to the ground in Tell Hermez, during a battle with the Syrian Army. This was part of a series of Daesh attacks conducted in the Hasakah province that targeted Christian settlements, destroying over thirty villages.

Sputnik News Service reported that between March 15, 2011, and December 15, 2015, Daesh destroyed St. George's Church in a bomb blast in the Hasakah Province of Syria. This was part of a series of Daesh attacks conducted in the Hasakah province that targeted Christian settlements, destroying over thirty villages.

Sputnik News Service reported that between February 1, 2015, and February 28, 2015, Daesh blew up the Church of the Mother of God in Tell Tamer. This was part of a series of Daesh attacks conducted in the Hasakah province that targeted Christian settlements, destroying over thirty villages.

Agence France Presse reported that between May 21, 2015, and December 9, 2015, ISIS destroyed archaeological features in Palmyra. Palmyra, which is 130 miles east of Damascus, was one of several cities seized by ISIS, some of which were recaptured by Iraqi forces.

Sputnik News Service reported that between August 1, 2015, and August 31, 2015, Daesh militants destroyed the Temple of Bel and the Baalshamin Temple in Palmyra. The Temple of Bel was dedicated to the Mesopotamian god Bel, while the Baalshamin Temple was dedicated to the Cannonite sky deity Baalshamin.

Sputnik News Service reported that between October 1, 2015, and October 31, 2015, Daesh militants blew up the Arch of Triumph in Palmyra. Also known as the Monumental Arch, this site was built in the 2nd century as a Roman oranamental archway.

TMISRA reported that on December 23, 2015, Syrian Government helicopters reportedly targeted the city of Bosra, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The city contains an historic citadel, ruins, and well-preserved Roman Theater. Parts of an ancient citadel in southern Syria, including its uniquely preserved 2nd century Roman theatre, were damaged.

The Syrian Directorate of Antiquities and Museums reported on December 22, 2015, Bosra was damaged. The ancient city of Basra is a Syrian World Heritage Site. Severe damage was inflicted to the western courtyard adjacent to Bosra’s 2nd century Roman theatre and to parts of the Ayyubid citadel which surrounds it through shelling and military activity.
ABCTRS reported that between January 28 and February 11, 2016, Russian air strikes hit a mosque in Aleppo.

ZEIT Online reported that on February 23, 2015, ISIS smashed an organ the Assyrian Church of Saint Mar Zia in Tell Goran. The church and many of Tell Goran's inhabitants belong to the Assyrian Church of the East, an ancient Christian sect.
Qatar Tribune reported that between March 15, 2011, and February 13, 2016, the Russian military struck a mosque in Idlib.
Independent online reported that between March 15, 2011, and February 16, 2016, the al-Nusra Front smashed the minaret of a local mosque in the al-Qadam district of Damascus.

CNN Newsroom reports that between March 15, 2011, and February 13, 2016, Syrian government forces destroyed and burned out many buildings in old town Aleppo. Old town Aleppo is a designated UNESCO heritage site and a major tourist destination as one of Syria's largest and historic towns.

NPR reported that between March 3, 2015, and February 28, 2016, fighting between forces loyal to Assad and Syrian rebels reduced much of the Aleppo Souq to nothing. The Aleppo Souq is part of the Old City of Aleppo and a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

NPR reported that before February 28, 2016, fighting between forces loyal to Assad and Syrian rebels destroyed the minaret of the Great Umayyad Mosque in Aleppo.  The Mosque is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

The Associated Press reported that between March 21 and  25, 2015, historic souqs in Bosra al-Sham were destroyed during fighting between insurgents and government forces. Bosra is recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage site.

Reuters reported that between March 21 and 25, 2015, a mosque in Bosra al-Sham was damaged during fighting between insurgents and government forces. Bosra is recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage site.

The Association for the Protection of Syrian Archaeology took a video of severe damage to Bosra, Syria, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Bosra was the home to a 2nd century theater and early Christian ruins. Most of the damage is the result of several aerial bombings performed by Syrian regime forces.

FARS News Agency reports that on July 15, 2016, the Syrian army retook southern parts of Darayya, which included retaking of a building in the Eastern part of the Nour al Deen Shahid Grand Mosque. While under rebel occupation, the building was used to produce bombs.

Global Stream reports that on July 14, 2016, Syrian Military forces, with Russian backing, destroyed al-Aqsa Mosque in an airstrike while attacking the rebel held Al-Hilwaniyeh neighborhood in Aleppo.

FARS News Agency reports that on the July 26, 2016, heavy shelling from Syrian tanks hit Jame'a Mosque in the al-Zahra neighborhood as they attempted to target the al-Qaeda affiliated al-Nusra front which had its command center in the neighborhood.

FARS News Agency reports that on August 2, 2016, the Syrian army attacked terrorist strongholds in Daraa city, hitting the northern side of the al-Khalil Mosque. This was a part of several attacks by the Syrian army to push out terrorist forces from the city of Daraa.
FARS News Agency reports that on August 6, 2016, The Syrian army recaptured the Bilal Mosque in the Darayya countryside in an effort to regain control in the area.

The French Press Agency reports that in February 2016, the Islamic State captured and destroyed Tell Ajaja, also destroying statues and cuneiform tablets found at the Assyrian-era site. IS was chased out of the site by Kurdish fighters in February 2016. It is reported that IS has destroyed aboout 40% of Tell Ajaja.

FARS News Agency reports that on Saturday August 6, 2016, Syrian sodiers stormed the eastern side of the al-Omari mosque whch was occupied by the Fatah al-Sham front at the time. Fatah al-Sham, previously known as the al-Nusra Front, had established strongholds in Daraa province.

The Times UK reports that between March 15, 2011, and August 26, 2016, ISIS blew up the second-century Lion of al-Lat statue. The remnants of this statue was found after the city of Palmyra was recaptured in March 2016 with Russian help.
Xinhua News Agency reports that the Shiite shrine of Sayyida Zaynab in Darayya, Damascus has been repeatedly attacked and bombed by Sunni-led rebels.
DPA reports that before September 15, 2016, ISIS destroyed the Temple of Bel in Palmyra. The Temple of Bel was dedicated to the Mesopotamian god Bel.
CNN Newsroom reports that in 2016, the Russian military reports it has killed 250 ISIS fighters in an airstrike north of Palmyra. This strike was meant to prevent ISIS from retaking Palmyra.

Kathimerinin English Edition reported that on May, 9, 2016, Syrian army airstrikes and shelling damaged the The Maarat al-Numan Mosaics Museum in the Idlib Governorate, Syria. This is the third time that the museum has been severely damaged, even after attempts to clean up the damaged areas and prevent any future destruction.

Kathimerinin English Edition and La Stampa reported that sometime between July 19, 2011, and December 31, 2011, ISIS militants and treasure hunters looted and severely damaged the ancient site of Apamea, near Hama, Syria. Apamea was an an ancient Greek and Roman city, now found in present-day Syria, on the Orontes River.

NPR: Morning Edition and the Associated Press Newswires reported that between March 24 and March 28, 2016, during one of the ISIL occupations of Palmyra, Syria, two marble busts were defaced and damaged. The busts, dating back to the 2nd or 3rd century, were later transported and restored to be on display at an exhibit at the Colosseum in Rome, Italy, along with other historical and cultural artifacts from Palmyra.

The Sunday Times reported that on either April 28 or April 29, 2015, clashes between Syrian government forces and rebels caused the Cathedral of Forty Martyrs to be targeted by bombing. The cathedral is a significant part of the Armenian community of Aleppo, Syria, as it has been standing since the 1400's.

properties.sitename: Khalil al-Wazir and Saad Sayil graves
properties.description: Ma'an News Agency reported that on October 17, 2016, Islamic State fighters bulldozed and smashed the graves of two Fatah cofounders. The graves were of Khalil al-Wazir and Saad Sayil.

The Sunday Times and The New York Times reported that during the capture of Aleppo, Syria, sometime in September 2012, rebels damaged the Khan al-Wazir market/caravanserai by burning it and shooting it with bullets. Khan al-Wazir is one of the oldest markets in Aleppo, and is located among other markets in the Al-Madina Souq in Aleppo, Syria. Many shops in the Al-Madina Souq were severely damaged by bombs and fires in September 2012.

Publico Online reported that sometime in March 2013, Mari experienced its first instance of heavy looting and illegal excavations. Mari is an ancient Mesopotamian city in Syria. At the site, thousands of looting pits were found. Looters, most likely consisting of Islamic State militants, armed gangs, and civilians, took huge quantities of ancient artifacts.

Agence France Presse reported that sometime in March 2013, Crac des Chevaliers experienced its first instance of damage by bombing, shelling, and looting as a result of the Syrian Civil War clashes. Crac des Chevaliers is a Medieval Crusader castle located near Homs, Syria.

Agence France Presse and SOUEST reported that sometime between May 1, 2014, and May 22, 2014, ISIS militants and looters destroyed hundreds, possibly thousands of ancient Assyrian statues, monuments, and sculptures in Tell Ajaja, Syria. Ancient goods were also looted from Tell Ajaja. Tell Ajaja, or ancient Saddikanni, is an ancient Assyrian-era archaeological site in Syria.

Canberra Times reported that on August 18, 2015, Islamic State militants publicly beheaded Khaled al-Assad, a Syrian archaeologist and the antiquities director of Palmyra.  Al-Assad refused to give out sensitive information regarding remaining artifacts, so ISIS beheaded him and hung his body from one of the ancient Roman columns in Palmyra, Syria.

Sputnik News Service reported that sometime in May 2015, during the ISIL occupation of Palmyra, Syria, many cultural and historical artifacts were looted from Palmyra, then found in Geneva, Switzerland in December 2016. This instance was the first instance of looting in Palmyra, which continued into early 2016 as well. Some artifacts are suspected to have also come from Libya and Yemen.

The Sunday Times and The Associated Press reported that on April 24, 2013, fighting between Syrian government forces and the rebels destroyed the minaret of Great Umayyad Mosque in Aleppo, Syria. The minaret was destroyed by shellfire.

Interfax Russia & CIS General Newswire and Agence France Presse reported that in June 2015, ISIL militants damaged the Lion of Al-Lat Statue while occupying Palmyra, Syria. The Lion of Al-Lat Statue stands near the Temple of Al-Lat; both structures are dedicated to the ancient Arabian goddess, Al-Lat.

The Times reported that on May 27, 2015, Islamic State militants used the Roman amphitheatre in Palmyra, Syria as a place for public executions, sometimes in front of crowds. Those executed included Syrian government troops.

Reuters News reported that during the capture of Aleppo, Syria, sometime between April 1, 2013 and April 24, 2013, ancient artifacts such as teeth were found missing from the tomb of the Prophet Zakariah at the Great Umayyad Mosque in Aleppo, Syria.

The Associated Press reported that on August 30, 2015, Islamic State militants blew up and destroyed part of the Temple of Bel. The Temple of Bel is an ancient temple located in modern-day Palmyra, Syria.

The Peninsula reported that between January 1, 2014 and February 22, 2014, fights between the Syrian army and the rebels caused damage to the Hammam Al-Nahasin, one of the oldest bathhouses in Aleppo, Syria.

The Peninsula reported that between January 1, 2013, and April 30, 2013, fights between the Syrian army and the rebels caused damage to the Al-Shibani church school. Located in Aleppo, Syria, the Al-Shibani church is currently used as a center for cultural exhibitions. However, in the past, it has been used as an Islamic school, a university, and a tobacco warehouse.

The Times reported that in September 2012, fighting between the Syrian Armed Forces and the Free Syrian Army caused heavy damage, by bombs and fires, to the Al-Madina Souq in Aleppo, Syria. The Al-Madina Souq is the largest covered market in the world.

The Times reported that on August 19, 2016, the Free Syrian Army blew up and damaged Beit Ghazaleh in Aleppo, Syria. Beit Ghazaleh is one of Aleppo's greatest and oldest palaces. The palace is a great showcase of architecture from the Ottoman period in Aleppo.

The Times reported that on August 19, 2016, the Free Syrian Army blew up and damaged Beit Achiqbash in Aleppo, Syria. Beit Achiqbash is an old mansion famous for its courtyard, originally built in the 18th century by Karah Ali, a Christian merchant.

The Times reported that in April 2015, Syrian rebels blew up Al Hatab Square using tunnel bombs. Located in the old Jdeidah quarter of Aleppo, Syria, Al Hatab Square was the center of the quarter and one of the oldest squares in the city. The quarter itself is home to many historical and cultural landmarks, such as various churches, mosques, palaces, and mansions.

The International New York Times reported that sometime between May 23, 2015, and May 31, 2015, during the ISIL occupation of Palmyra, Syria, Islamic State terrorists blew up monuments that were found on historical sites in Palmyra, Syria.

The International New York Times reported that sometime between May 23, 2015, and May 31, 2015, during the ISIL occupation of Palmyra, Syria, Islamic State terrorists smashed statues that were found on historical sites in Palmyra, Syria.

The Herald reported that sometime between December 1, 2014, and December 17, 2014, Dura-Europos was significantly looted. Dura-Europos is an ancient Roman border city found today near Salhiyah, Syria. Occasionally, Dura-Europos is also dubbed, "Pompeii of the desert."

The Syrian Arab News Agency reported on May 25, 2014 that churches and monasteries in Homs were damaged from the conflict. The variety of churches and mosques represents Syria's religious diversity. The city is also close to the Crac des Chevaliers castle, a World Heritage Site.

The Syrian Arab News Agency reported on May 25, 2014, the Khaled Ibn al-Walid Mosque in Homs was damaged from the conflict. The mosque is dedicated to Khalid ibn al-Walid, a 7th century military commander, and includes a mausoleum in which his body was housed prior to the conflict.

The National reported that between April 1, 2012, and May 26, 2014, the ancient site of Hamoukar in the Al Hasakah Governorate was looted and destroyed. Hamoukar is an ancient civilization dating back to the 5th century BCE and is recognized as an important trade post on the route to Anatolia. It is now a large archaeological site located in the Jazira region of northeastern Syria and includes artifacts from trade posts and the ancient civilization of Mesopotamia.

The National reported that between April 1, 2012, and May 26, 2014, the ancient site of Tell Ajaja has been looted and destroyed. Tell Ajaja, or ancient Shadikanni, was one of the main cities of Assyria or Mesopotamia. The site included Assyrian statues, columns, tablets, and scripts among various other artifacts dating back to 2,000-1,000 BC.

NPR reported that before May 27, 2014, antiquities were looted from the 1st century Roman settlement Apameia, outside the Syrian city of Homs. Apameia is an ancient Greek and Roman city that once was the capital of the Macedonian protectorate of Syria and played an important role in the crusades. The site contains remains of the Hellensitic era such as temples, castles, and the Great Colonnade among other artifacts of life during that time.

NPR reported that before May 27, 2014, 24 statues and Roman arches were looted from Palmyra. Palmyra is an ancient Semitic city that includes archaeological finds dating back to the Neolithic period. It has also been classified as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

The Jerusalem Post reported that between May 23 and 25, 2014, Syrian Army Forces completely destroyed the Eliyahu Hanabi Synagogue in in the Jobar neighborhood of Damascus. The synagogue was once a Jewish pilgrimage site and Syria's oldest Synangogue. It was situated atop a cave thought to have served the prophet Elijah in hiding.

The Toronto Star reported that on May 31, 2014, persistent militant bombardments and periodic raids by Islamist rebels would burn and sack the dozens of churches located in Homs. The variety of churches and mosques represents Syria's religious diversity.

It was reported on June 3, 2014, that a mosque in the al-Kalaseh district in Aleppo was damaged by an air strike. Al-Kalaseh is a rebel held neighbourhood of Aleppo and contains a variety of places of worship.

The Daily Telegraph reported that on June 3, 2014, the Jamaa al–Haddadeen, the Mosque of the Blacksmiths, was destroyed by a barrel bomb. The extent of the damage includes the mosque's doors, courtyard, and ancient stone pulpit.

It was reported on June 5, 2014, that a mosque in the Qadi Askar district in Aleppo was damaged by a barrel bomb. Qadi Askar is a rebel held neighbourhood of Aleppo and contains a variety of places of worship.

properties.sitename: Khalid Ibn al-Walid mosque and mausoleum
properties.description: The Independent reported that between May 29, 2014, and June 5, 2014, that the Mosque of Khalid ibn al-Walid, as well as the grave of al-Walid, was blasted by shellfire and bullets. The mosque is dedicated to Khalid ibn al-Walid, a 7th century military commander, and includes a mausoleum in which his body was housed prior to the conflict.

The Independent reported that on June 5, 2014, the Homs Orthodox Church was damaged in conflict, causing its roof to be missing. The bust of a cleric also has bullet holes in its face and shoulders as a result.

The Independent reported that on June 5, 2014, the French-built Homs Museum was damaged by rounds of rifle shots and grenades thrown by rebels. The museum holds a large repository of Islamic art like ceramics.
The Christian Science Monitor reported that between March 15, 2014 and May 14, 2014, citizens and FSA fighters looted exposed ruins in Palmyra.

Associated Press reported that between March 1 and May 5, 2014, the the Syrian Military bombed Crac des Chevaliers. Crac des Chevaliers, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, was held as a rebel stronghold when the Syrian Military bombed it with airstrikes and Heavy Cannons.
Xinhua News Agency reported that on May 6, 2014, Rebels bombed a graveyard in Damascus. The mortar that struck the graveyard was one of dozens that have killed and injured many civilians.
Xinhua News Agency reported that on May 6, 2014, rebels bombed a mosque in Damascus. The Mortar that struck the mosque was one of dozens that have killed and injured many civilians.

Central Asian News reported that in April 2011, the Othman Mosque in Daraa was damaged. Syrian security forces occupied the mosque and desecrated it with graffiti. A Tunisian jihadist who goes by the name Abu Qusay, told Tunisian television that his goal in Syria was to destroy and desecrate mosques with Sunni names in false-flag sectarian attacks to encourage defection by Syrian soldiers.

Central Asian News reported that in April 2011, the Abu Bakr Mosque in Daraa was damaged. Syrian security forces occupied the mosque and desecrated it with graffiti. A Tunisian jihadist who goes by the name Abu Qusay, told Tunisian television that his goal in Syria was to destroy and desecrate mosques with Sunni names in false-flag sectarian attacks to encourage defection by Syrian soldiers.

Postedia reported that between May 7, 2012, and May 7, 2014, rebels set fire to the St. Elian Monastery in Homs. According to the source, all 11 churches in the old quarter of Homs have been damaged or destroyed.
FARS News Agency reported that on May 8, 2014, militants damaged archaeological sites in the Old City of Aleppo, a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

properties.sitename: Khalid Ibn al-Walid Mosque and Mausoleum
properties.description: The New York Times reported that between March 15, 2011, and May 10, 2014, fighting between the Syrian Military and rebels damaged the Khaled bin al-Walid Mosque in Homs. The mosque also contains the Mausoleum of Khalid ibn al-Walid, a 7th century Arab military commander.

Al-Arab reported that between March 15, 2011, and May 10, 2014, rebels damaged and vandalized an Armenian church in Homs. The façade of the building was damaged and anti-Assad graffiti was painted on the walls.

ANSAMED reported that between March 15 and May 14, 2014, rebels vandalized and burned the Umm Al-Zenar Cathedral in Homs. The Umm Al-Zenar Cathedral which is a Syriac Orthodox cathedral and the seat of the Syriac Archbishop of Homs and Hama was looted, burned, and vandalized with sectarian graffiti.

properties.sitename: Shrine of the Prophet Hazrat Zakaria
properties.description: Daily Messenger reported that between March 15, 2011, and May 16, 2014, terrorists attacked the shrine of the Prophet Hazrat Zakaria in Aleppo.
Syrian Arab News Agency reported that between March 15, 2011, and May 26, 2014, fighting between the Syrian Military and rebels damaged churches in Homs.

Al Akhbar reported that between  March 15, 2011, and June 17, 2012, the Syrian military took position in the Castle of Ibn Maan, also known as Palmyra Castle or Qalaat Fakhr ad-Din al-Maani. The castle is thought to have been built by the Mamluks in the 13th century, and overlooks the archaeological site of Palmyra.

properties.sitename: Church of Martyred Saints Sergius and Bacchus
properties.description: Reuters News reported that on March 1, 2013, a church in Deir Ezzor was  desecrated.

FARS News Agency reported that between April 1, 2013, and March 27, 2014, that an Al-Qaeda splinter group bombed the Shrine of Hazrat Fatemeh, a Shiite shrine in Al Raqqa. Before the war, the shrine was a site for Muslim pilgrams from Iran, Lebanon, and Iraq.
The Philadelphia Inquirer reported that between November 1, 2012, and November 30, 2012, Assad's forces attacked the Moadamiyeh neighborhood in Damascus.

Reuters News  reported that on March 25, 2014, an Al-Qaeda splinter group destryed a Sh'ite shrine and mosque in Al Raqqa. The Mosque of Ammar bin Yassir and the Shrine and Mausoleum of Uwais al-Qarni were destinations for Shi'ite pilgrims before the war.

Reuters News  reported that on March 25, 2014, an Al-Qaeda splinter group destryed the Mosque of Ammar Ibn Yasser, a Sh'ite shrine and mosque in Al Raqqa. The Mosque of Ammar bin Yassir and the Shrine and Mausoleum of Oweis al-Qarni were destinations for Shi'ite pilgrams before the war.

The Middle East reported that between July 1, 2013, and July 31, 2013, Bashar Assad's forces destroyed the 13th century Crac des Chevaliers, a Crusader castle built by the Knights Hospitaller. Syrian rebels, including Lebanese Salafists under Khaled Al Mahmoud, had taken shelter in the castle for the pat several months during the bombardment.
The Middle East reported that between October 1, 2011, and April 1, 2014, Bashar Assad's army tanks attacked Aleppo's famous Umayyad Mosque, first built in 634 AD.
The Middle East reported that between October 1, 2012, and April 1, 2014,  months of fighting left the Medieval covered souq of Aleppo, one of the oldest markets of its kind, in ruins.

The Middle East reported that between October 1, 2012, and April 1, 2014, street fighting destroyed the Aleppo's Temple of the Storm God, a 5,000 year-old structure which depicts ancient religious reliefs along the temple.

The Middle East reports that between March 15, 2011, and April 1, 2014, government forces destroyed the Roman ruins at Palmyra. Anceint Palmyra was built in an oasis, and was an important trade route linking the Middle East with Asia and Europe.

India Public Sector News reported that on March 23, 2014, there have been recurrent attacks by al Qaeda against Christians and Christian churches in Kessab, leading to the expulsion of many Christians from their homes.

BBC Monitoring Newsfile reported that between November 1, 2013, and November 30, 2013, Armenian educational centers were targeted, among them the Surb Sargis church, and the Armenian Catholic Gymnasium. At the Armenian Catholic gymnasium in Damascus, around 60 people were wounuded, and around 6-7 Armenians wounded.

The New York Times reported that between March 15, 2011, and April 17, 2014, Palmyra was been the site of various attacks, leaving its ancient city destroyed, and museums subjected to looting of ancient relics. The ruins are being used by the Syrian military, and the illegal digging and sale of artifacts has persisted across Syria since the conflict began.

properties.sitename: Shrine of Sheikh Abu Umama al-Bahili
properties.description: Al Akhbar reported that between January 1, 2014, and April 24, 2014, the Shrine of Sheikh Abu Umama al-Bahili was damaged in the village of Deir Ful, which is mostly populated by Circassians of Dagastani descent. In this period, the town was taken over by ISIS. Fighting between ISIS and the Al-Nusra Front caused daily shelling and bombing of the city.

properties.sitename: Shrine of Sheikh Ezzeddine Abu Jarra
properties.description: Al Akhbar reported that between January 1, 2014, and April 24, 2014, the Shrine of Sheikh Ezzeddine Abu Jarra was damaged in the village of Deir Ful, which is mostly populated by Circassians of Dagastani descent. In this period, the town was taken over by ISIS. Fighting between ISIS and the Al-Nusra Front caused daily shelling and bombing of the city.
Dow Jones Institutional News reported that between March 15, 2011, and April 25, 2014, the Great Umayyad mosque was damaged.

Al Akhbar reported on June 6, 2013, that the Syrian army had taken over the village of Hamidiyeh a few days prior. The local mosque was used as a center of operations for the Syrian army, and exhibited bullet holes as a result of the minaret being used by a sniper.

The Wall Street Journal reported on June 6, 2013, that mosques in Qusayr had been damaged during conflict. Qusayr had recently been taken over by the Syrian government, after a struggle between government forces and rebels, and had also been the site of conflicts between Sunnis and Shiites, as well as between Muslims and Christians.

The Wall Street Journal reported on June 6, 2013, that St. Elias's, the main Christian church in Qusayr, had been damaged by a tank and defaced by anti-Assad graffiti, and that depictions of Christ's crucifixion had been removed from paintings and altarpieces. The church was damaged partially during Qusayr's takeover by Assad loyalist forces, but was also desecrated by Sunni militant rebels that had been linked to al Qaeda.

The Times of India reported on June 7, 2013, that looters had removed Byzantine-era mosaics from Northern Syria's Dead Cities during the Syrian Civil War. The Dead Cities, a series of settlements from the Byzantine period, are important archaelogical sites and one of Syria's six UNESCO world heritage sites.

The Times of India reported on June 7, 2013, that looters had removed Byzantine-era mosaics from the Roman city of Apamea during the Syrian Civil War. The site of Apamea is now a town and Medieval fortress called Qalaat al-Madiq.

The Times of India reported on June 7, 2013, that the Syrian Army had established bases in Aleppo during the Syrian Civil War, resulting in damage to the ancient citadel. The Ancient City of Aleppo is one of Syria's six UNESCO world heritage sites.

The Times of India reported on June 7, 2013, that rocket fire had damaged the outer wall of Crac des Chevaliers during the Syrian Civil War. Crac des Chevaliers is an 11th century Crusader castle located in Homs, and is one of Syria's six UNESCO world heritage sites.

The Times of India reported on June 7, 2013, that al-Nustra, an armed anti-government group, had used the Ma'arra Mosaic Museum, based in a 17th century caravan trading post building, as a base in Ma'arrat Al-Numan. This led to the destruction of several artifacts.

The Times of India reported on June 7, 2013, that the ruins of the Roman-era city of Bosra, in the Daraa district, had been damaged during the Syrian Civil War. Bosra is an important archaeological site and one of Syria's six UNESCO World Heritage Sites.

The Times of India reported on June 7, 2013, that ruins in Palmyra had been damaged during the Syrian Civil War. Palmyra, an ancient Semitic city located in present-day Homs, is one of Syria's six UNESCO World Heritage Sites.

The Times of India reported on June 7, 2013, that an 8th century BC Aramaic bronze statue had been listed by Interpol as stolen from the Hama Museum. This looting took place during the Syrian Civil War, when historic monuments and artifacts were damaged by both rebels and government forces.

The Times of India reported on June 7, 2013, that the Syrian Army had established a base in the ancient citadel in Homs during the Syrian Civil War. The Citadel Of Homs dates back to the 3rd Millenium BCE.

FARS News Agency reported that on June 11, 2013, the Al-Nusra Front set fire to mosques in the Hatlah district of Deir Ezzor. Al-Nusra, a Salafist jihadist organization, also killed 60 Shiite Muslims, in an angry response to the Syrian army's successful takeovers in Qusayr.

BBC Monitoring European released an excerpt of the Italian newspaper La Stampa, which reported that on June 11, 2013, Salafi combatants destroyed a Shiite mosque in the Hatla district of Deir Ezzor. This occurred during a massacre perpetrated by Al-Nusra, a Sunni extremist group.

BBC Monitoring Middle East released a report from Syrian news agance SANA on June 14, 2013, which reported that authorities had stormed a terrorist den in the countryside in Palmyra, and seized stolen archaeological artifacts. Artifacts from the Byzantine and Roman ages, such as mosaics and statues, were looted from ruins across Syria during the civil war.

properties.sitename: Tomb of Sakina bint Imam Hussein
properties.description: FARS News Agency reported on June 15, 2013, that militants had infiltrated the Western side of the Hazrat Sakina shrine in Damascus. The shrine is located near the original burial place of Sayeda Sakina, the daughter of Husayn ibn Ali, who was the third Shia Imam and the grandson of the prophet Muhammad.

BBC Monitoring Newsfile reported that on June 19, 2013, Syrian Satellite Channel Television relayed the news that terrorists had torched a Syriac church located on the main street in Deir Ezzor. Syriac Christianity is a branch of Eastern Christianity.

BBC Monitoring Middle East reported that on June 19, 2013, an improvised explosive device went off in the Al-Midan neighborhood of Damascus, near the destroyed Fatimah al-Zahra Mosque. The explosion occurred while the Syrian army was conducting air raids in the area, but it is unclear whether the mosque was damaged in this incident, and which side of the conflict inflicted the damage.

Agence France Presse reported that on June 20, 2013, UNESCO added the Ancient City of Aleppo to the list of endangered World Heritage Sites. Aleppo suffered major damage during the Syrian Civil War and conflict, which began with the revolt in March of 2011.

Agence France Presse reported that on June 20, 2013, UNESCO added the Ancient City of Bosra to the list of endangered World Heritage Sites. Bosra contains Roman and Byzantine ruins, and was damaged during the Syrian Civil War.

Agence France Presse reported that on June 20, 2013, UNESCO added the oasis of Palmyra to the list of endangered World Heritage Sites. Palmyra is an ancient Semitic city and archaeological site, and was damaged during the Syrian Civil War.

Agence France Presse reported that on June 20, 2013, UNESCO added Crac des Chevaliers to the list of endangered World Heritage Sites. Crac des Chevaliers, a Medieval Crusader castle from the 11th century located in present-day Homs, was damaged during the Syrian Civil War.

Agence France Presse reported that on June 20, 2013, UNESCO added Qa-lat Salah al-Din to the list of endangered World Heritage Sites. Qa-lat Salah al-Din, also known as Sahyun Castle, is a Medieval castle located near the present-day town of Al-Haffah, and was damaged during the Syrian Civil War.

Agence France Presse reported that on June 20, 2013, UNESCO added the ancient city of Damascus to the list of endangered World Heritage Sites. Damascus, Syria's present-day capital, was founded in the 3rd millenium BCE, and was damaged during the Syrian Civil War.

Agence France Presse reported that on June 20, 2013, UNESCO added the Dead Cities of northern Syria to the list of endangered World Heritage Sites. The Dead Cities, a group of settlements that date back to the Byzantine Period, are important archaeological sites that were damaged during the Syrian Civil War.

CNN Wire reported that on June 5, 2013, an ancient mosque in Qusayr was damaged in a takeover by the Syrian Army, with the help of Hezbollah, a Lebanese radical Islamic shiite militia. The minaret of the mosque was described as sustaining severe damage including a gaping hole.

CNN Wire reported that on June 5, 2013, St. Elias Church in Qusayr was damaged in a takeover by the Syrian Army, with the help of Hezbollah, a Lebanese radical Islamic shiite militia. Some of the icons inside the church were defaced.

CNN Wire reported that on June 5, 2013, the clock tower in the central square of Qusayr was damaged in a takeover by the Syrian Army, with the help of Hezbollah, a Lebanese radical Islamic shiite militia.

Reuters News reported on June 21, 2013, that Sunni rebel fighters called  al-Muntasereen Billah ("God's Victors") took over the Ammar bin Yassir Mosque in Raqqa in March, and smashed open tombs that contained Shi'ite figurines. The mosque used to be a pilgrimage destination for Shi'ite Muslims.

Reuters News reported on June 21, 2013, that rebel fighters had shot at the Sayyida Zaynab shrine in Damascus, damaging the minarets. The site was important to Muslims, especially Shi'ites, and was being defended by Lebanese soldiers.

Independent Online reported on June 21, 2013, that the Aleppo Souq had been burned during the Syrian Civil War. The Souq is a covered market located in the Ancient City of Aleppo, a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

Independent Online reported on June 21, 2013, that the Umayyad Mosque in Aleppo had been ruined by heavy fighting during the Syrian CIvil War. This mosque was built between the 8th and 13th centuries, and is said to contain the remains of John the Baptist's father.

The Toronto Star reported on June 22, 2013, that the city of Apamea had been damaged by shelling in 2011, during the Syrian Civil War. Apamea was originally founded in 301 B.C.E., and was an ancient Greek and Roman city.

Independent Online reported on June 23, 2013, that a mosque in Qusayr had been smashed during a takeover by the Syrian Army earlier in the month. The mosque's minaret was described as lying on the ground.

Postmedia Breaking News reported on June 25, 2013, that the main mosque in Salaheddine, a district in Aleppo, had a dome pockmarked with bullets. The damage was likely inflicted by the Syrian Army, during the Syrian Civil War.

Newsweek reported on June 26, 2013, that the minaret of a mosque in Khan Assobl, a town in the province of Idlib, had been damaged by tank fire. Khan Assobl was a frequent target for attacks from the Syrian Army during the Syrian Civil War.
